prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Reglet’s Rampant Furnibeast**

Beware the Furnibeast, my bold,
Whose clatter-clanks the pressroom hold—
It slithers past the ink-stained trays,
And gnaws the leads in midnight frays!

The reglet trembles, thin and pale,
As quads go *sproing!* and type turns frail.
“O take your chase!” the foreman cried,
But none dared face its gape so wide.

The Furnibeast came whiffling through,
With *snick-snack* jaws and glue like dew.
It munched the ems, it slurped the ens,
Then spat out pi in tangled ends!

But lo! The stick—so swift, so true—
Came down with *thwack!* and *squelch!* and *threw*!
The beast let loose a mottled shriek,
And fled in kerflumps, bleak and meek.

O hark! The press now hums once more,
The reglets stand as they before.
Yet mark the ink—there lurks a stain…
*The Furnibeast may come again!*
label: medium
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "The Reglet’s Rampant Furnibeast" appears separately and non-empty before the first stanza—criteria met.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 6 stanzas; all are quatrains with 4 lines each—total stanza count between 5 and 8 inclusive; meets criteria.</C2_think>

<C4_think>Rhyme pattern (2,4) rhymes/slant rhymes present in at least 4 stanzas. Rhyme pairs include: hold/frays (no), wide/wide (repeated word), through/ends (no), true/bleak (no), more/before (yes), stain/again (yes). Only about half show clear rhyme/slant in lines 2 and 4; also no dominance of AABB pattern visible. Rhymes are sporadic and weak overall, so less than 60% with 2,4 rhyme—does not meet.</C4_think>
<C5_think>The final stanza echoes the opening somewhat in theme (press, reglet, stain), but does not reuse ≥2 content words or a clear refrain line from the first stanza. No strong ring composition evidence.</C5_think>
<C6_think>An early admonition "Beware the Furnibeast, my bold" is present in the first stanza—a clear warning/admonition.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Before the encounter stanza, the foreman encourages action ("O take your chase!"), but protagonist preparation (tool preparation or resolve) is implicit; no explicit armament described but "The reglet trembles" and call to chase suggest readiness/preparation—accept as modest preparation.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear encounter occurs in stanza 3 where the Furnibeast "came whiffling through" and acts aggressively on "ems" and "ens"—evident confrontation.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive act in stanza 4: "the stick—so swift, so true—/ Came down with *thwack!* and *squelch!* and *threw!*" where the beast shrieks and flees; a clear resolution.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration in stanza 5: "O hark! The press now hums once more... The reglets stand as before." The tone is calm, not jubilant; no joyous acknowledgment or "beamish"-style joy; more cautiously optimistic but no strong celebration—does not meet fully.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinages: Furnibeast, reglet, clatter-clanks, sproing, thwack, squelch, kerflumps; at least 7 distinct invented coinages appear. Possibly short on one coinage to meet 8 or more—borderline no.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Coinages are spread: first stanza has clatter-clanks, second has sproing, third has whiffling/snicksnack*, fourth has thwack, squelch, threw (onomatopoeic), fifth no clear coined word, sixth with kerflumps. So ≥1 coinage in most stanzas except the 5th; since 1 stanza out of 6 lacks it, that's ~83% coverage, so meets criterion.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Named creature is "Furnibeast," which is non-canonical; central to action; "The reglet" seems like a named object/place, not creature. Creature naming criterion met.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia: *sproing!*, *snick-snack*, *thwack!*, *squelch!*, *threw!* — at least two clear onomatopoeic bursts present; meets criterion.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance present in stanzas 1 ("clatter-clanks the pressroom"), 3 ("spat out pi in tangled ends"), and 4 ("swift, so true"); more than two stanzas demonstrate this clearly—meets criterion.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order: warning ("Beware"), preparation ("O take your chase!"), encounter (Furnibeast appears), decisive act (the stick strike), return (press hums again). This order is preserved canonically; meets criterion.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No exact verbatim lines from the canonical Jabberwocky are present; all lines are original or modified—meets criterion.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens such as "whiffling," "snick-snack," used once or twice but total canonical tokens well within 8 distinct tokens; mostly new coinages dominate—meets criterion.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable counts approximate the Jabberwocky pattern: longer lines about 8–9 syllables, shorter lines about 5–7 (e.g. stanza 1 lines go roughly 9/7/8/7); maintains tight syllable control in all quatrains—meets criterion.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety is limited; some end words repeat ("wide" repeated in stanza 2 lines 3 and 4 rhymes), "again" and "stain" rhyme, but several stanzas do not rhyme at lines 2 and 4 or reuse same rhyme word; rhyme variety is under threshold—does not meet.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No single content word repeated excessively; no significant lexical overuse detected; meets criterion.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages root variety: Furnibeast, reglet, clatter, sproing, thwack, squelch, kerflumps, snick-snack; roots diverse, suffixes not dominant; meets criterion.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic adherence is consistent: poem addresses a "Furnibeast," a creature in a setting resembling a pressroom vs. the original Jabberwock; although new subject, the poem is an evident homage not substitution with unrelated topic—whether allowed depends on given topic. Since no topic was supplied, assume addressing a Jabberwocky-style creature and narrative generally consistent—accept.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext is moderate: warning vs. an industrial pest, preparation, confrontation, defeat, and cautious aftermath. An implied theme of vigilance vs. recurring threats. This motif is coherent across poem—meets criterion.</C24_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Bliterwisp’s Twirl**

Beware the blued screw’s twirling whine,
That gnaws the gear with *flicker-squeak*—
The cogs all shudder, out of line,
When wispworms in the darkening leak.

Take up your spanner, grip it tight,
And oil your joints with *glim and gleam*,
For slithy shafts may bolt by night,
And *clankle* loose what once did seem.

Then through the workshop, dim and deep,
You’ll spy the Bliterwisp’s *skritch-scur*—
Its rusty eye, its coil’s creep,
The *thrumble* of its turning blur!

One strike! The wrench goes *snick-snap* clean,
The screw stands still, its spin undone—
No more the *whirrick*, sharp and keen,
No more the *jink* of bolt from sun.

O frabjous day! The lathe stands true,
The belting hums a steady tune—
Yet mark its gleam… that ghostly blue…
Beware the blued screw’s next *flicker-squeak*.
label: high

<C23_think>Topic adherence: poem clearly addresses a mythical mechanical creature "Bliterwisp," aligning well with the Jabberwocky theme of a dangerous, whimsical adversary -> yes</C23_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Stubbleflit’s Vorpal Dance**

Beware the flittermere at eve’s dim glow,
When stubble hisses, sharp and sere—
The wispwing whirls in twilight’s woe,
And skirls the air with whispers queer.

O grease thy boots and gird thy sight,
For there the Stubbleflit may rise,
With snickering snath and feather-light,
And murkle-maddened, murkle-eyes.

The flock did gyre, the flock did gnarl,
Their beaks a-clatter, *chit-chit-chur!*—
Till forth there leapt the bristling Snarl,
And split the sky with one dark *purr!*

Then blade met plume in flicker-flash,
The stubble cracked like brittle bone—
One snick! One snatch! The Snarl did thrash,
And left the field in silence, lone.

O frabjous day! The flitters fled,
No more their spooky spirals spin—
Yet hark! A rustle, soft and dread…
*The stubble hisses—* **takes thee in!**
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line present and separate from first stanza content (in bold and on top) -> yes</C1_think>
<C2_think>Stanza count = 6; all stanzas have 4 lines (6 between 5 and 8 inclusive) -> yes</C2_think>

<C4_think>Rhyme on lines (2,4) appears in 4 or more stanzas out of 6 (≥67%), rhyme seems mostly slant rhyme or true rhyme, no overwhelming AABB dominance (mostly ABAB or ABCB pattern implied) -> yes</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza does not clearly repeat ≥2 content words or phrases from opening stanza; no clear refrain; echo of theme but no ring composition -> no</C5_think>
